links.description: Widely known for his obsessive pursuit of Jackie Kennedy Onassis, tabloid photographer Ron Galella is often referred to as the ‘godfather of paparazzi’. The title of the documentary refers to Onassis’s directive to her security guard to ‘break his camera’.

links.description: The term paparazzi comes from a character called Paparazzo, an invasive news photographer played by Walter Santesso in Federico Fellini’s lauded film. The director compared the name paparazzo to a term for an oversized mosquito.

constellations_other.name: Weaving a Dark Web
constellations_other.description:
In contemporary Hollywood cinema, children's films often align with comedy and musical genres. However, harking back to the days of European fairytales (and certainly beyond), children's stories are historically dark in tone and were written for both children and adult audiences alike. 
With an apocalyptic threat looming large, Moomins and the Comet Chase veers more into darker territory. However, it is the talented voice cast that conjures some connections to some pure cinema darkness.

links.description: Lady Gaga’s music video ‘Paparazzi’, starring Alexander Skarsgard and directed by Jonas Akerlund, was inspired by celebrity experiences with intrusive photographers, including Princess Diana.

links.description: La Dolce Vita and Michelangelo Antonioni’s L’Avventura both premiered at the 1960 Cannes Film Festival. While the former received the Palm d’Or, the latter was booed. Six years later, Antonioni released this film about a fashion photographer who believes he’s captured a murder on film.

key_work.title: Cinema orchestras and organs
key_work.brief_description: Melbourne’s Capitol Theatre became the home of the first large Wurlitzer Organ in the country, which was used to provide music and sound effects for silent films when the orchestra was not performing, while the Palais Pictures theatre had its own in-house orchestra.

end.brief_description: This work consists of 7 dual-channel installations. As viewers enter the exhibition space, they are faced by found footage of iconic performances delivered by seven popular Hollywood female leads and then paired with a version by Candice Breitz delivering the lines.

links.description: Many critics felt Hepburn’s performance of Eliza Dolittle was inauthentic because she didn’t sing. Candice Breitz, in her multi-channel video work, explores the idea of authenticity and stardom by substituting her voice for the voices of famous female leads.

links.description: A barely visible boom-mic blooper is trifling. More significant is The Mandalorian‘s compelling soundscape, including the distinctive sound of the darksaber. The changing pitch of the original lightsaber in Star Wars came from recording the sound with a moving mic.

results.name: Ladies who own the narrative
results.description: Despite the lag in making it in mainstream cinema, female action heroes can actually be traced back to the late 19th century in early magic lantern performances of Jane Conquest, who saved both her child and a ship full of men.

key_work.title: Jane Conquest magic lantern slides
key_work.brief_description: Dramatic and emotional magic lantern shows like Jane Conquest were hugely popular and were often performed like plays, with scripts, songs and poems. This famous tale follows Jane as she cares for her sick child while her husband is lost at sea.

start.title: His Girl Friday
start.creator_credit: Howard Hawks and Jed Harris
start.brief_description: Hildy, the journalist former wife of newspaper editor Walter Burns, visits his office to inform him that she’s engaged and will be getting remarried the next day. Walter can’t let that happen and frames her fiancé to keep her in her job.

end.title: Mad Men
end.creator_credit: Blake McCormick, Jon Hamm, Tom Smuts and Dan Bishop
end.brief_description: Don Draper (Jon Hamm) tries to balance his successful career in advertising with his wavering personal life in the tumultuous period of change during the 1960s. Deftly scripted and featuring memorable characters, Mad Men is one of the highlights of prestige TV.

constellations_other.name: Power and infamy
constellations_other.description: Beginning with an anamorphic image of Napoleon III, this Constellation focuses on representations of the distorted perspective of patriarchal power.

links.description: Peggy Olson similarly triumphed in the traditionally male dominated world of 1950s and 60s advertising. Starting the series as a shy secretary bewildered by the flashy Madison Ave agency, Peggy blossoms over the series into a headstrong creative genius.

constellations_other.name: Representation of women in videogames
constellations_other.description: Ms Pac-Man is the first famous female game protagonist, but let's face it – she's just Pac-Man with a bow. This Constellation looks at the history of female representation in videogames.

constellations_other.description: Explore the interconnections between queer period dramas, through to sci-fi and surrealistic worlds.

constellations_other.description: Despite the lag in making it in mainstream cinema, female action heroes can actually be traced back to the late 19th century in early magic lantern performances of Jane Conquest, who saved both her child and a ship full of men.

links.description: Like Jane, Ellen Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) was also an ordinary woman who rose to meet extraordinary circumstances, taking down both extraterrestrials and gender stereotypes. Though the role was originally written for a man, it’s hard to imagine anyone but Weaver kicking alien ass.

constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: The heroes in Hustlers were similarly underestimated and undervalued by the men around them. Tired of being pushed around, objectified and used, single mothers Romana and Destiny spearheaded a plot to take care of themselves and their families one greedy sulky man at a time.

end.title: Toast
end.brief_description: “Humour is a universal language,” says Edie Kurzer, and it’s an element she weaves into much of her artistic output. It’s also something that attracted her to the unique portraiture work of Sydney artist Heather Mitchell. Better known for her stage and screen presence, Mitchell has found a growing audience for her toast portraits of Australian celebrities in her medium of choice: Vegemite. Creating these slices especially for our display, she has shone a tasty spotlight on some of our most singular screen faces such as Josh Thomas, Lee Lin Chin, Deborah Mailman and others.

end.title: Pukar
end.creator_credit: Rajkumar Santoshi, Bharat Shah, Boney Kapoor, Surinder Kapoor, S K Film Enterprises and Anjum Rajabali
end.brief_description: Major Jaidev Rajvansh (Anil Kapoor) and his fellow officer Hussein (Om Puri) manage to rescue a leading politician as well as capture his kidnapper, Abhrush (Danny Denzongpa). The terrorist has been wanted for years and he is finally captured by the two officers. Jai returns to a joyous welcome, and is declared a national hero. He takes a break from the army and returns to his hometown. There he meets his childhood friend Anjali (Madhuri Dixit) who has always harboured love for Jai. Anjali is determined to make sure she and Jai stay together 24/7. At a party, he meets Miss India, Pooja Mallapa (Namrata Shirodkar). As they spend more time together, he begins to love her and she too begins to love him. In the mean time, Jai’s parents are arranging his marriage to Anjali but when they find out about Jai’s love for Pooja, they realise that they have to tell Anjali everything.

key_work.brief_description: Documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. results.description: The Toupie Fantoche relies on four prismatic mirrors to reflect changes in animation states.

key_work.title: Toupie-fantoche (Spinning Top)
key_work.brief_description: Charles-Émile Reynaud wasn’t content with only inventing the praxinoscope. In 1881 he simplified his own design, creating a new portable optical toy called the toupie-fantoche, or ‘spinning top’. Typical scenes included butterflies fluttering, dogs jumping through hoops and drummer boys drumming.

recommendations.quote: De Niro’s Travis Bickle is one of the key figures of American cinema; the passage of his taxi through the grubby, smoky streets of the city – accompanied by the great composer Bernard Herrmann’s final score – are unforgettable. links.description: Mirrors also play an important role in the character arch of Travis Bickle in Taxi Driver yet rather than saving Bickle, encapsulating his decent into violence. Bickle appears fractured between the macho man in the mirror and his real self who is instead lost and lonely.

key_work.title: US Navy Ciné-Kodak Special
key_work.brief_description: Eastman Kodak introduced the Ciné-Kodak Special in 1933. The silent 16mm camera was durable and lightweight enough to be used by combat photographers working in the field and Kodak manufactured a military version in all-black without the usual chrome edges.

key_work.title: Jedda
key_work.credit_line:
Courtesy Chauvel Film Enterprises Pty Ltd

Jedda is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
key_work.brief_description: Jedda is beloved by many First Peoples for being Australia’s first film with Aboriginal lead roles. But despite being a first for First Peoples representation, it also reflects deeply problematic times in Australia, characterised by policies of assimilation and forced removel of Indigenous children.

constellations_primary.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_primary.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

Jedda is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
start.brief_description: Jedda is beloved by many First Peoples for being Australia’s first film with Aboriginal lead roles. But despite being a first for First Peoples representation, it also reflects deeply problematic times in Australia, characterised by policies of assimilation and forced removel of Indigenous children.

constellations_primary.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_primary.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

end.title: Q&A
end.brief_description: Hosted by Hamish Macdonald, Q&A puts punters, pollies and pundits together in the studio to thrash out the hot issues of the week. It’s about democracy in action - the audience gets to ask the questions.

links.description: While the depiction of First Peoples in Jedda reflects colonial views of the times, actor Rosalie Kunoth-Monks was inspired to become an activist by the experience. She made a memorable Q&A appearance, where she declared “Don’t try and suppress me and don’t call me a problem, I am not the problem.”
